metadata.title: Performance evaluation of double stage process using nano hybrid PES/SiO2-PES membrane and PES/ZnO-PES membranes for oily waste water treatment to clean water

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Environmental Chemical Engineering
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jece
Performance evaluation of double stage process using nano hybrid PES/ SiO2-PES membrane and PES/ZnO-PES membranes for oily waste water treatment to clean water
Tutuk Djoko Kusworoa,⁎, Qudratunb, Dani Puji Utomoa
a Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Diponegoro, Semarang, Indonesia bNano Center Indonesia, South Tangerang, Indonesia
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keyword: Double stages Nano-hybrid membrane NanoSiO2 Nano ZnO Produced water
A B S T R A C T
Membrane-based separation is a technology that recently developed by researchers, especially in wastewater treatment. Implementation of membrane technology in oil wastewater treatment is limited due to its low productivity as a result of fouling on the membrane surface. The introduction of nanomaterials has been developed to the produced nano-hybrid membrane with better performance. In this paper, nano-hybrid polyethersulfone (PES) membranes contained nano SiO2 and ZnO are fabricated and evaluated for produced water treatment in a double stages configuration. The nano-hybrid PES membranes are fabricated using dry-wet phase inversion to form flat sheet membranes. The membrane filtration cell is set in double stages configuration with nano-hybrid PES membrane in the first stage and neat PES membrane in the second stage. In this study, separation performance of nano-hybrid PES-nano SiO2 and PES-nano ZnO is compared and discussed. Fouling behaviour of the membranes is also revealed. Experimental results show that the nano-hybrid PES-nano SiO2 membrane has 25% higher permeate flux than the nano-hybrid PES-nano ZnO. Comparing overall improvements of double stages performance with single stage confirmed that the final flux enhanced by 200%, mineral rejection efficiency improved by 16–18%, and the lower foulant deposition on the membrane. The performance enhancement of nano-hybrid membrane is restricted by the loading concentration where the agglomeration doesn’t occur. It is expected that this study can provide guidance for improving new strategies to facilitate PES membrane-based separation as an effective and efficient technology for produced water treatment.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
High consumption of conventional oil and gas in Indonesia emerges a significant problem in the waste disposal management. Spills of produced water have become major environmental issues in enhancing oil and gas production [1,2]. Produced water is generated in large quantities as co-product of oil well production along with the oil and gas product [3]. The produced water is known as the most significant waste stream from the oil and gas refineries containing a lot of pollutants, consist of: (i) dissolved and dispersed solid, (ii) dissolved oil and grease, (iii) dissolved gases, (iv) soluble and insoluble organics, and (v) dissolved minerals [4]. The concentration of pollutants in produced water are varying and highly depends on the geological location. Alzahrani et al. [5,6], stated that, in general, the concentration of pollutants in produced water were 1.2–200 mg L−1 for dissolved oil and grease, 1000–15,000 mg L−1 for total dissolved solid, and 20 to 2250 mg L−1 for organic contents. The pollutant’s content in produced
water can cause several problems including tubular equipment corrosion, migrating loading, scaling formation in heat exchanger, and environmental damage if the water is disposed of directly [7]. Considering the environmental hazardous of produced water, a proper wastewater management is required to treat produced water before being disposed or reused for certain purpose.
The utilization of produced water as oil wells water injection sometimes induced the micro-scale earthquake and cause the contamination of surface water [3]. Geological consideration for water injection, technological and economic barriers for disposal requirement, water scarcity issue, and other management methods have led to increasing the interest in evaluating the produced water potential for reuse. General processes in produced water treatment are (i) removing dispersed oil and grease, (ii) soluble organic removal, (iii) suspended solid removal, (iv) dissolved gas removal such as light hydrocarbon gases, carbon dioxide, and hydrogen sulfide, (v) desalination to remove salts, (vi) softening to remove excess water hardness, and (vi)

disinfection to eliminate microbial pathogens [8,9]. For the current research, the technology is focused on finding an effective and efficient, fewer chemical addition, low equipment cost, and quick process for produced water treatment. Membrane technology offered an attractive solution for produced water treatment with many advantages such as low-cost treatment, no toxic chemical additives, modular installation, and it operates at ambient temperature [2,10].
Membrane-based separation processes such as microfiltration, ultrafiltration, nanofiltration and reverse osmosis are commonly used for produced water treatment. In addition, some of these processes can be combined to achieve high removal efficiencies [11]. However, this process has primary challenge known as membrane fouling caused by oil droplets and soluble organics [12,13]. Many studies have been performed to develop the separation properties of membrane material and lowering the fouling during operation. Cross-linking, photografting, polymer blending, and incorporation of inorganic fillers have been introduced in enhancing membrane separation performance. Zha et al. [14], studied operating pressure effect, and salt concentration on PES/SiO2 based TFC hollow fiber membrane performance for oilfield produced water. They stated that membrane had high separation efficiency along with pressure increase. Nasrollahi et al. [15] stated that polyethersulfone (PES) membrane with nanoparticles incorporated successfully improved the anti-compaction capability during pressure treatment, the permeability and antifouling behaviour of the membrane. Lin et al. [16] investigated the performance of nano-WS2 embedded PES membrane in term of permeability, fouling resistance, and solute rejection. They found that in general, fouling resistance, permeability, and solute rejection significantly enhanced. Kusworo et al. [17] found that the incorporation of nanoparticle as inorganic filler generated unselective nano-gaps between polymer and filler which cause the decrease of separation efficiency. They tried to overcome the nano-gaps problem by immersing the membrane in silicone rubber solution, ultraviolet irradiation, and thermal annealing treatments. To reduce the membrane fouling, many researchers developed membrane with anti-fouling properties by modifying the membrane structure through ultraviolet irradiation, thermal annealing, organic solvent immersion, and membrane coating [18–20]. These efforts are focused on membrane material modification, one of the critical factors affecting the membrane separation performance is membrane configuration.
In this study, produced water is treated to obtain clean water using nano-hybrid PES membrane with the novel concept of double stages configuration. In the first stage, nano-hybrid PES membrane with the incorporation of nanoSiO2 and nano ZnO was employed. The first stage is aimed to reject higher dispersed particulates including dispersed solids, oil droplets, and organic matters. The second stage applied neat PES membrane with lower pore size to reject mineral pollutants. With this configuration, is expected to reduce the occurrence of fouling on the membrane due to large particulates deposition. Based on the literature studies, there is no information on the concept of double stages process with different pore size membranes utilization. Specifically, the separation performance of nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2 and PES-nano ZnO is compared and discussed. Moreover, the fouling behaviour of the membrane is revealed. It is expected that this study can provide guidance for improving new strategies to facilitate PES membrane-based separation as an effective and efficient technology for produced water treatment.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials selection
sections.text:
Polyethersulfone (PES) was purchased from Solvay Advanced Material (USA). The polymers were dried in a vacuum oven at 120 °C overnight before being used. N-methyl-pyrrolidinone (NMP) as a solvent and Polyethylene glycol (PEG) 4000 g mol−1, both from Merck was used. Nano-SiO2 and nano-ZnO as inorganic nano-filler were
supplied from Nano Center Indonesia with the nanoparticle specification are shown in Table 1. In order to remove the adsorbed water vapour or other organic vapours, nanoSiO2 and nano ZnO were dehydrated at 300 °C for 3 h before use. An original produced water sample from PT Pertamina Oil & Gas Company, Ltd was used as the feed. Pure distilled water as non-solvent was obtained from the Integrated Laboratory University of Diponegoro.

sections.heading: 2.2. Membrane fabrication process
sections.text: In this study, the first stage included nanoSiO2 and nano ZnO incorporated to PES matrix to produce nano-hybrid membrane as the membrane material. On the other hand, the second stage used neat PES without any additive. The membranes were fabricated by preparing a dope solution and then the solution was cast into flat sheet membranes via dry-wet non-solvent induced phase inversion (NIPS) technique.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Neat PES membrane fabrication
sections.text: Neat PES membrane was manufactured by preparing a dope solution with 25 wt-% polymer concentration. An appropriate mass of PES polymer was first dissolved in NMP under constant stirring to form a homogeneous solution. The mixture was kept for 12 h, then was degassed under the atmospheric condition for 24 h to remove air bubbles. The flat sheet neat PES membrane was prepared by dry-wet phase inversion using manual casting knife. The casted dope solution film on flat gas immediately was immersed in non-solvent (pure distilled water) and soaked for 24 h at room temperature to ensure the complete separation of solvent. The flat sheet neat PES membrane was dried in drying chamber at room temperature [21].

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2 and PES-nano ZnO membrane fabrication
sections.text:
Nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2 membrane and PES-nano ZnO membrane were fabricated by preparation of stable and homogeny polymer dope solution [22]. The nanoSiO2 powder was blended together with the polymer solution in another container. An appropriate amount of nano ZnO was mixed with NMP solvent, wherein the nanoparticles are dispersed uniformly in the membrane solution. For the preparation of the dope solution, 1.5 wt-% of nano-fillers from total solid was added first to the N-methyl Pyrrolidone solvent and stirred for three h to avoid nanoparticle aggregation. Two wt-% of PEG was added to the solution, then 18 wt-% of Polyethersulfone (PES) was added under constant stirring for 12 h to obtain stable and homogeneous dope solution. The dope solution was allowed to stand for four h under slow mixing, and the solution was heated at 60 °C to remove air bubble and also to keep homogeneity of nanoparticles in the solution. The prepared polymer dope solution was cast on a smooth flat glass plate by a manual casting knife with constant speed, where the membrane thickness was sustained at 150 μm. The membrane on the glass plate was modified by subjecting the membrane under Ultraviolet ray for 2 min. Subsequently,
the dope solution on the flat glass was solidified by immediate immersion in a coagulation bath containing pure distilled water as nonsolvent at room temperature (30 ± 2 °C). The membrane was released from the glass plate and kept for 24 h to ensure complete solvent separation from the membrane. Finally, the membranes were dried by placing them in the drying chamber for 24 h at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of original produced water sample
sections.text: Original produced water sample was characterized to analyze the concentration of dispersed oil and grease, soluble organic, total dissolved solids (TDS), suspended solids, and salts/minerals. Produced water was filtered using filter paper, an appropriate volume of the water samples was taken for TDS test using TDS meter test kit. Salts content was defined using Mohr titration expressed as NaCl content. Sulfide ions concentration was determined by iodometric titration, and organic content was considered as total COD in a sample using permanganometric titration. The oil and grease content was expressed as total hydrocarbon which is analyzed via Gas chromatography-Mass spectrometry analysis.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Scanning electron microscope (SEM)
sections.text: The morphology of neat PES, nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2, and PESnano ZnO membranes were characterized by Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) JEOL series JSM-6510-LA, Japan. A piece of flat sheet fabricated membranes were first immersed in liquid nitrogen and fractured using tweezers, and then sputter coated with gold for SEM examination. Through this analysis, it can be seen the cross-sectional (1,000×) and the surface (20,000×) morphology of the membrane with a certain magnification.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Molecular weight cut-off, average pore radius, and porosity of membrane
sections.text:
Molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) of membrane represents the lowest molecular weight of solute (in Dalton) in which the membrane rejects 90% of the solute. The MWCO value is a membrane characterization method to describe the pore size distribution and retention capabilities of membranes. In this work, the solute rejection experiments were performed using polyethylene glycol (PEG) as polymer solute at the various molecular weight (600 Da, 1 kDa, 4 kDa, 6 kDa, and 10 kDa). The PEG solution was prepared in 1 wt-% concentration and then filtrated in a dead-end filtration cell. The permeate samples were analyzed using a visual handheld refractometer Atago. The molecular weights vs solute rejections were plotted, and the molecular weight corresponding to 90% rejection was estimated as MWCO of the
membrane [23]. Further, the MWCO was used to estimate the average pore radius of the membranes by using Eq. (1) [24].

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Water contact angle measurement
sections.text:
Water contact angle values of pure PES membrane and nano-hybrid PES membranes were measured using water contact angle meter. Deionized water was used as a probe liquid, and when deionized water droplet was put on the membrane surface, the water contact angle was immediately average measured at three times of each left and right side of the membrane [26].
2.5. Separation performance test of the fabricated membrane using double stages configuration
Nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2 and PES-nano ZnO membranes were utilized in the produced water treatment experiment. Flat sheet membrane with an effective area of 12.76 cm2 was mounted in the membrane cell. A dead-end system membrane cell filtration was configured as double stages as shown in Fig. 1. In the first stage, nano-hybrid PES membrane was mounted, and the second stage the neat PES membrane was used. A two- liters feed vessel was filled with distilled water, and then the water was fed to the membrane for compaction process as long as 15 min. After compaction process, the distilled water was replaced with original raw produced water. The produced water temperature in the vessel was kept at room temperature (30 ± 2 °C). Then produced water was continuously fed to the membrane by turning on the water pump 1, the pressure in the upstream was regulated by controlling the valves. The permeate water was drawn from the membrane module to the permeate tank first stage; periodically the permeate water was sampled to be analyzed the permeate water flux and rejection. According to Fig. 1, after the permeate water in the permeate tank 1
reached the appropriate level, the second water pump was turned on. The permeate water in tank 1 was then continuously fed to the second stage membrane cell. The permeate water from the second membrane cell was collected in the permeate water tank 2. The permeate water was measured for the flux calculation and rejection at predetermined time periods. The equations to evaluate permeate water flux and rejection is given in the Eqs. (3) and (4) bellow [20,21]:

sections.heading: 3.1. The characteristics of original produced water sample
sections.text:
Produced water contains oil-in-water emulsions, where the oil is dispersed in the water. The composition of produced water varies dependent on oil field geological structure and usually changes as the oil fields ages. The main components of produced water are dispersed oil and grease, dissolved organics, suspended solids, and dissolved inorganic salts/minerals. In order to select the proper method for managing produced water as clean water, the study will first focus on produced water characterization. The specific suitable method can be preferred by understanding the characteristics of produced water. The characteristics of produced water sample are presented in Table 2.
Based on Table 2, the characteristics of a produced water sample is categorized as low pollutants produced water. The TDS concentration was found as 5000 ppm for original feed produced water, while the typical TDS concentration in produced water is ranging from 1000 until 29,000 ppm. The dispersed oil and grease in produced water based on Table 2 is 0.15 ppm. This value is much lower than general oil content
in produced water ranging from 1.2 to 565 ppm [5,6]. Even though the pollutants concentration is relatively low, it still in excess of clean water quality requirements and hence the proper produced water treatment is needed. The low concentration of oil and grease dispersed in produced water indicated low bio-fouling risk on the membrane surface.
As listed in Table 2, the average pollutants concentration of permeate water collected from stage 1 and stage 2 are still higher than maximum allowable standard. However, the total oil and grease, turbidity, appearance, and sulfide contents meet the quality requirements for clean water. The high TDS and salts concentration in permeate could be due to the pore deformation during the drying process and formed the unselective voids. These voids reduce selectivity performance of the membrane. The membrane should be soaked immediately in methanol and hexane after being solidified in the non-solvent bath to replace the water molecules within the polymer when drying process the methanol and hexane easier to evaporate than a water molecule so that it can maintain the pore structure from deformation. From Table 2, it can be observed that double stages significantly enhance the quality of permeate water.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) result
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows the surface morphology of (a) the neat PES, (b) nanohybrid PES-nano ZnO, and (c) nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2 membranes at 20,000 times magnifications. It can be seen in Fig. 2(a) that the surface of neat PES membrane is smooth, no pores could be observed at this magnifications. It indicates that the pores size is in nano-scale. The membrane is very dense, and there are no unselective nano-gaps in the membrane surface. White spots found on the membrane surface are polymer clumps, which may be caused by the un-simultaneous membrane solidification during coagulation process in the non-solvent bath.
The surface morphology of nano-hybrid PES-nano ZnO membranes can be seen in Fig. 2(b). It is observed that the nano ZnO particles assembled together in a point of the membrane surface. This nanoparticles agglomeration domain could cause the low efficiency of rejection due to the formation unselective nano-gaps [27]. The agglomeration of nano ZnO could be due to the inhomogeneous dope solution. On the other hand, the shape and affinity of ZnO particles with polymers are also the important factors in nano-particles agglomeration domain in membrane surface.
As shown in Fig. 2(c), the surface morphology of nano-hybrid PESnanoSiO2 membrane is smooth and dense. The appearance of nanoSiO2 particles are very rare on the membrane surface layer. It may be the nanoSiO2 are embedded in the sublayer of the membrane. This phenomenon could be due to the good affinity between nanoSiO2 particles and PES matrix [22]. The embedded nano-particles in the sub-layer of PES membrane are helpful in enhancing the anti-compaction behaviour of the membrane thus resulting in relatively stable permeate water flux [28]. In this membrane, there are no unselective voids on the membrane; it indicates that the nanoSiO2 are well attached to PES polymer. It corresponds to the previous research that SiO2 particles are the best nano-fillers in PES membrane due to its adhesive properties with PES polymer.
Fig. 3 showed the cross-sectional SEM image of fabricated membranes. Fig. 3a is cross-sectional SEM image of neat PES with 1000 x magnification. The slow demixing of polymeric solution resulting in less porous finger-like sponge structure of membrane sublayer. The average thickness of membrane based on SEM image (Fig. 3a) was 60 μm consisting of a dense layer on the top layer, porous support layer in the intermediate layer. The cross-sectional SEM images of nano-hybrid PES membranes with 1000 x magnification were displayed in Fig. 3.b,c, and d. The appearance of membrane structure was similar to Fig. 3a; it consists of dense layer and finger-like porous structure. The average thickness of the nano-hybrid membrane was also 60 μm lower than neat PES membrane. These scan images confirmed the asymmetric structure
of the membranes.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. MWCO, average pore radius, and porosity results
sections.text:
The MWCO measurements were carried out using PEG method. Fig. 4 shows the plot PEG molecular weight vs solute rejection. The MWCO values were obtained when the solute rejections were 90%. In term of MWCO values, there was a different value between PES 25% and PES 18%. Neat PES membrane was fabricated by polymer concentration of 25 wt-%, while nano-hybrid PES membranes were fabricated by polymer concentration of 18 wt-%. Based on Table 3, neat PES membrane’s MWCO value was 2850 ± 132 Da much lower than nanohybrid PES membranes which had similar MWCO values. The MWCO
values represented the pore size distribution of membrane. Membrane pore size was the important factor in membrane selectivity.
The fabricated membranes in this work were nanofiltration membrane based on the pore radius of the membrane. The nanofiltration membrane was classified as a membrane that has pore size diameter ranging from 1 to 10 nm. The pore size radius of nanoSiO2 incorporated PES membrane has higher pore radius than nano ZnO incorporated PES membrane. This could be due to the diameter of nanoparticles size which is used in this work. NanoSiO2 has larger particle size than nano ZnO; the smaller particles will be easily attached in a polymer matrix which produced smaller pore radius. The porosity of membrane represented the void fraction in the membrane, a higher porosity of membrane provides higher permeate flux. Based on Table 3, neat PES membrane has the lowest porosity due to its higher polymer concentration. Polymer concentration contributes to membrane sub-structure formation. The high polymer concentration in dope solution produced a viscous solution. This is well known that viscous dope solution caused the delayed demixing process during the coagulation process. This such process delivers in low porosity membrane.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Water contact angle of the membrane
sections.text:
In this work, the water contact angle measurement a static contact angle measurement type. A static contact angle is captured when a thermodynamic equilibrium is reached between the three phases: solid, liquid, and gas. This measurement provides valuable information on the surface properties. The contact angle higher than 90° indicates a hydrophobic surface with poor adhesiveness, poor wettability, and low solid surface free energy. In contrast, the contact angle lower than 90° usually indicates a hydrophilic surface, good adhesiveness, good wettability, and high solid surface free energy. The favourable membrane for water treatment is a hydrophilic surface with good wettability to enhance the permeate productivity. Table 4 shows the contact angle measurement results for each fabricated membrane.
Based on Table 4, contact angle values of neat PES, PES-nano ZnO, PES-nano ZnO + UV, and PES-nanoSiO2 membranes were 75.08°, 62.58°, 59.17°, and 65.25°, respectively. The neat PES membrane had the highest contact angle value indicated that PES has slightly hydrophilic properties. All of PES membranes blended with nanoparticles showed the lower contact angle values. Nanoparticles were well known as hydrophilic properties contributed on nano-hybrid membranes. It was also confirmed that nano-hybrid PES membranes showed low water contact angle values. UV irradiated PES-nanoZnO membrane provided the lowest contact angle value; it confirmed that UV irradiation strongly enhanced the hydrophilicity of the membrane. This result may be attributed the hydrophilic functional groups formation through methyl oxidation. The most hydrophilic membrane based on this work are UV irradiated PES-nano ZnO>PES-nano ZnO>PES-nano SiO2 > neat PES membranes. NanoZnO embedded PES membrane has higher hydrophilic properties than nanoSiO2 embedded PES membrane because ZnO has a higher affinity for water than SiO2 even though nanoSiO2 embedded PES membrane has a smooth surface.

sections.heading: 3.3. Separation performance of nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2 and PES-nano ZnO
sections.text:
The separation performance in term of permeate water fluxes as a function of time is shown in Fig. 5 for nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2 and PES nano ZnO membrane in the first stage. Permeate water fluxes through both membranes declined by 60% for PES-nanoSiO2 membrane from 30 until 11.8 Lh−1m−2bar−1 after 150 min operation, and decline by 52% for PES-nano ZnO membrane from 19.5 until 9.3 Lh−1m−2bar−1 after 150 min operation.
The permeate fluxes of different membrane materials are shown in Fig. 5(a). For all time-dependent flux profile, a sharp decline at the beginning of filtration process was observed. This could be due to organic particles as well as oil droplets deposition on the membrane
surface and internal fouling because of the particles and oil droplets migrated to the bulk of membrane. In the several cases, the incorporation of nanoparticles in the membrane matrix increased the permeate flux by increasing nanoparticles concentration until a certain value of the concentration of nanoparticles. This phenomenon occurred for hydrophilic particles only, where the introduction of hydrophilic particles such as SiO2 enhanced the hydrophilicity of the membrane which improved the permeate flux. This experimental result corresponds to the previous research reported by Pu et al. [29]. However, further increase in concentration results in permeate flux reduction which may be due to the formation of nanoparticles agglomerates.
Based on the flux profile illustrated in Fig. 5(a), it could be found that average permeate flux of PES-nanoSiO2 membrane is higher by 25% than PES-nano ZnO. It might be due to the hydrophilicity of SiO2 particles is higher than ZnO because of the number oxygen molecule in a mole of SiO2 which plays as a negative charge. Besides that, the incorporation of nano ZnO in PES matrix polymer at a concentration of 1.5 wt-% forms an agglomeration of nanoparticles (as shown in Fig. 2) which significantly decrease the permeate water flux, while in the nanoSiO2 incorporation at the same concentration has not yet formed an agglomeration. Agglomeration of nanoparticles was affected by several factors such as the adhesive property of particles and the shape of particles. Overall, the positive effect of nanoparticles incorporation on the permeate water flux is limited by the critical concentration of nanoparticles where the agglomeration isn’t formed. These results are in accordance with previous research reported by Ismail et al. [30].
Fig. 5(b) shows that the UV irradiation on the PES-nano ZnO significantly enhanced the permeate water flux about 25%. Where the average permeate flux of unmodified nano-hybrid membrane is 13.8 Lh−1m−2bar−1 while the modified membrane is 17 Lh−1m−2bar−1. This permeate water flux enhancement wasn’t followed by the changing in TDS rejection efficiency. From the illustrated profile in Fig. 5(b), the TDS rejection efficiency of unmodified and modified nano-hybrid PES-

This could be due to the UV irradiation on the membrane surface only changed the chemical structure become more hydrophilic without caused any significant change in the structural morphology. This corresponds to the previous research conducted by Seman et al. [31], and Kusworo et al. [17,21]. Kusworo et al. [17,21], stated that the UV irradiation for 2 min on the PES membrane increased the dense layer in the membrane substructure due to the polymer cross-linking within PES polymer chains. This result corresponds to water contact angle measurement result, in which the contact angle value of UV irradiated nano-hybrid membrane was the lowest.
3.4. Permeate water flux performance in double stages configuration
Two configuration systems of double stages were performed for produced water treatment. The first configuration comprised nano-hybrid PES-SiO2 membrane in the first stage and the neat PES 25% membrane in the second stage. The second configuration employed the nano-hybrid PES-nano ZnO membrane in the first stage and neat PES 25% membrane in the second stage. The profile of permeate water fluxes for all configuration system was monitored and illustrated in Fig. 6.
Fig. 6 shows the variation of permeate water flux for oilfield produced water treatment in second stage process. The permeate fluxes of all membrane configurations are slightly declined. The system with nano-hybrid PES-nanoSiO2 configuration shows the decline in permeate flux by 36% from 1.6 until 1.0 L h−1 m−2bar−1 while the system with nano-hybrid PES-nano ZnO configuration shows the flux decline by 39% from 1.8 until 1.1 L h−1 m−2bar. Even though in the second stages were used the same membranes (neat PES 25%), it shows different permeate flux profile with the different membrane in the first stage (PES-nanoSiO2 and PES-nano ZnO). The higher permeate flux of PES-
nano ZnO configuration than PES-nanoSiO2 was due to the better quality of first stage downstream product which is used as feed in the second stage. The nano-ZnO embedded PES membrane is estimated having better behaviour in rejecting organic material (e.g oil droplet) because of its hydrophilicity of the membrane and lowering fouling tendency [32,33]. Hydrophilic membrane easily rejects the hydrophobic oil droplet contained in oily produced water since the repulsive force between oil molecules and membrane material [34]. The lower oil content in the permeate product of the first stage reduces the possibility of fouling which lowering the permeate flux in the second stage. The flux declines of the second stage are dominantly caused by pore blocking as a result of membrane compaction not due to irreversible fouling. With this experimental results are known that the membrane type of the first stage greatly determines the membrane performance in the second stage.
3.5. Rejection efficiency performance in double stages configuration
Several researchers have reported the incorporation of nanoparticles such as nanoSiO2 and nano ZnO in the membrane material can improve the membrane performance especially membrane rejection efficiency. In this study, the rejection efficiency of PES-nanoSiO2 and PES-nano ZnO in the first stage and neat PES 25% in the second stage were investigated. The average rejection of all membranes was displayed in Fig. 7. To obtain the information about rejection improvement by this proposed configuration, the rejection efficiencies of second stage membrane were compared with the rejection efficiencies of single stage consist of neat PES 25% membrane.
The rejection efficiencies in TDS and NaCl removal of all membrane
configurations were shown in Fig. 7. The observed rejection efficiencies are first stage permeate products; second stage permeate products and single stage permeate products. In the first stage consist of PES-nanoSiO2, PES-nano ZnO, and UV irradiated PES-nano ZnO, while in the second stage and single stage use the same membrane i.e. neat PES 25%. Based on Fig. 6, it shows that the rejection efficiencies of the first stage are much lower than the second stage, this is due to the PES concentration used in the first stage is 18 wt-% while in the second stage is 25 wt-%. The concentration of PES polymer in dope solution is an important factor that controls the pore size and structure. In the first stage, it is shown that the rejection of TDS and NaCl are similar for every three different membranes. This shows that the different nanomaterial embedded in PES membrane and UV modification on the membrane surface did not significantly affect the rejection efficiency of mineral. This result confirmed the previous research, Zoubeik et al. [35], and Jin et al. [36] studied the incorporation of hydrophilic nanoparticle such as SiO2 and ZnO improved the rejection of oil droplet from oily water and also significantly enhanced permeate water flux. This can be said that the incorporation of nanoparticles in the PES concentration of 18 wt-% did not give significant improvement in mineral rejection but very effective the improve organic removal.
The rejection efficiency for double stages process shows a significant improvement compared with single stage performance. The average rejections of double stages are 57% for TDS removal and 55% for NaCl removal which shows an improvement in rejection efficiency by 16–18%. This rejection improvement was due to minerals removal in the first stage and then followed by the second stage. Another advantage of this double stages process is higher permeate flux than a single stage. In other words, it can be said that the double stages process has better performance in terms of permeate flux and rejection efficiency than single stage process.

sections.heading: 3.6. Fouling analysis in the second stage of membrane process
sections.text:
Fouling is an important parameter in the membrane separation process since the fouling affects membrane productivity. Fouling in the membrane caused flux decline by two mechanisms: short-term pore blocking and long-term irreversible fouling. The analysis of membrane fouling can be conducted by observing pressure increase of the upstream section, permeate flux decline profile, or observe membrane surface through SEM and FTIR analysis as reported by previous researchers [17,37]. The pressure increase profiles of membranes in 2nd stage of double stages process and single stage process are displayed in Fig. 8. The upstream pressure was initially set at 8 bar gauge and continuously increase during filtration operation. The pressure increases were observed every 15 min.
All membranes show pressure increase during filtration process as shown in Fig. 8a. The pressure increases drastically in the initial process of filtration and shows a slight increase after 30–40 min operation. This pressure increase indicates the fouling formation on the membrane surface. Fouling occurs mostly due to pore blockage; there are four major blocking types on the membrane that are complete blocking, standard blocking, intermediate blocking, cake blocking [38,39]. The initial rapid pressure increase is mainly due to standard blockage of pore constriction caused by particle adhesion between particles in feed water and membrane materials. The adhesion force caused particle deposition on the walls of the membrane. The rapid pressure increase was followed by slight pressure increase due to cake formation over membrane surface. The particle deposition greatly changes the membrane pore which implies on sharp decline of flux, while cake layer formation can act as a solid-liquid separation medium which fairly decreases the permeate flux.
Fig. 8a also shows that the pressure increase of single stage filtration is much higher than double stages process, it could be due to the organic contents such as oil droplet was removed in the first stage. Oil droplet is the main actor of fouling formation in the membrane, if oil
droplet was wiped out in the first stage using low PES concentration, it would maintain the permeate flux in the second stage despite using a higher PES concentration membrane. To clarify, Fig. 8b was put up to show foulant deposition on the membrane surface. The neat PES 25% after being used in the single stage shows thick foulant layer on the membrane, while the neat PES 25% after being used in the 2nd stage of double stages process doesn’t show any foulant deposition on the membrane surface. The strategy of configuring the lower polymer concentration with nanoparticle embedded membrane as first stage membrane and higher polymer concentration membrane in the second stage is successful to obtain high permeate productivity, without decreasing rejection efficiency, and prevent the fouling formation.
3.7. Stability test of double stages process membrane filtration
The incorporation of nano-particles in membrane preparation tends to leach out from the membrane during filtration process [29,40]. When embedded nano-particles are released from membrane matrix, it will leave a cavity within the membrane causing a decrease in the rejection efficiency of the membrane and its mechanical strength. It further affects the poor quality of the first stage output permeates which directly affects on second stage productivity. The stability test was carried out by investigating the permeate flux profile of second stage membrane for 8 h and compared with the flux profile of single stage neat PES membrane to observe the improvement. The results of permeate flux decline profiles were displayed in Fig. 9.
The membrane stability was observed by measuring flux profile at a constant upstream pressure in the membrane cell system (Fig. 1). Fig. 9 shows the flux profile as a decline curve for all membranes. The rapid decline of fluxes occurs at the initial filtration process, 120 min of operation the permeate fluxes slightly decrease. The rapid flux decline is due to membrane pores constriction as result of particles attachment on membrane wall. The slight flux decline is due to cake layer formation on the membrane surface. Based on Fig. 9, it can be said that fabricated membranes have good stability without any nano-particle was leached out from membrane body. Table 5 is displayed to confirm that there was no nano-particle leaching from the membrane. The Zn and Si content in Feed and permeate produced water were analyzed using ICP. The results showed that the concentration of Zn and Si in permeate samples were lower than feed sample. It indicates that nanoparticles were not leached out from membrane body. This because the permeate flux profile of double stages are much higher than single stage process. If there is nano-particle (nano SiO2 and nano ZnO) release during filtration, then the permeate flux profile of double stages process will be similar to permeate flux of single stage process. Furthermore, the decline flux profile of single stage is sharper than double stages process; it indicates that there is more foulant deposition on membrane surface than membrane in double stages. By double stages configuration with the nano-particle embedded membrane in the first stage increases the permeate flux by 200% than single stage process and there is no nanoparticle release from membrane matrix due to strong affinity of SiO2 and ZnO particles with PES matrix.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The performance of nano ZnO embedded PES membrane is better than the nanoSiO2 embedded PES membrane in terms of permeate flux. The application of double stages configuration where nano-particles hybrid PES membrane implemented in the first stage and neat PES membrane in the second stage can improve the permeate flux by 200% and pollutant rejection efficiency by 16–18%. It also performed lower foulant deposition on the membrane surface compared with neat PES membrane. The implementation of nano-hybrid PES membrane in the first stage has an advantage where the nano-hybrid membrane can remove organic pollutants (e.g., oil droplets) better than the neat PES membrane. The fabricated nano-hybrid membranes exhibited good
stability without releasing nano-particles during filtration which may reduce the membrane performance. The performance enhancement of nano-hybrid membrane is restricted by the loading concentration where the agglomeration doesn’t occur. It is expected that this study can provide guidance for improving new strategies to facilitate PES
membrane-based separation as an effective and efficient technology for produced water treatment.

metadata.abstractText: Membrane-based separation is a technology that recently developed by researchers, especially in wastewater treatment. Implementation of membrane technology in oil wastewater treatment is limited due to its low productivity as a result of fouling on the membrane surface. The introduction of nanomaterials has been developed to the produced nano-hybrid membrane with better performance. In this paper, nano-hybrid polyethersulfone (PES) membranes contained nano SiO2 and ZnO are fabricated and evaluated for produced water treatment in a double stages configuration. The nano-hybrid PES membranes are fabricated using dry-wet phase inversion to form flat sheet membranes. The membrane filtration cell is set in double stages configuration with nano-hybrid PES membrane in the first stage and neat PES membrane in the second stage. In this study, separation performance of nano-hybrid PES-nano SiO2 and PES-nano ZnO is compared and discussed. Fouling behaviour of the membranes is also revealed. Experimental results show that the nano-hybrid PES-nano SiO2 membrane has 25% higher permeate flux than the nano-hybrid PES-nano ZnO. Comparing overall improvements of double stages performance with single stage confirmed that the final flux enhanced by 200%, mineral rejection efficiency improved by 16–18%, and the lower foulant deposition on the membrane. The performance enhancement of nano-hybrid membrane is restricted by the loading concentration where the agglomeration doesn’t occur. It is expected that this study can provide guidance for improving new strategies to facilitate PES membrane-based separation as an effective and efficient technology for produced water treatment.
